My beds are well furnish'd with fleas,</br>Whose bitings invite me to scratch;</br>Well stock'd are my orchards with bees,</br>And my pig-styes well cover'd with thatch.
Not a rose in my garden is seen,</br>But, cabbage and lettuce abound;</br>My borders with onions are green,</br>Leeks and garlick spread over the ground.
No fields in the prime of the year</br>More charms than my dairy display;</br>Meux and Reed cannot boast better beer</br>Than the pot-house just over the way.
I seldom a pimple have met,</br>Such health does magnesia bestow;</br>My horse-pond is border'd with wet,</br>Where the flap-docks and sting-nettles grow.
The Dutch nightingale's amorous tone</br>From its inmost recesses proceeds;</br>And I add to her wooings my own,</br>As I sit on my dunghill of weeds.
I have found out a gift for my fair,</br>In my Cheshire some rotten I've found:</br>But, let me the plunder forbear,</br>Nor give that dear bosom a wound!
For, tho' oft from her lips I have heard</br>That the rotten her palate would please,</br>Yet, he ne'er could be true, she averr'd,</br>Who would rob a poor mite of its cheese.
And where does my Dorothy stray?</br>And where are her pattens and clogs?</br>As dirty as our's is the way?</br>Is the country as fruitful in hogs?
The land may be fruitful in bogs,</br>And dirty may be all the ways;</br>The shepherds in manners like hogs,</br>For mine are the manners to please.
Lubin's pate is as bald as a stone,</br>His graces of youth are quite fled,</br>His teeth are all rotten, or gone,</br>And his eyes almost sunk in his head.
Then, tho' Lubin is rich, I'll not fear,</br>That an old man will rifle her charms,</br>But trust the good sense of my dear</br>Will conduct her to Corydon's arms.</br>
